Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 9. The Bodhisattva's Training in the Arts
Then the Boddhisattva, together with a retinue of five-hundred, went to the school of  Krimivarman, the master of scripts, who is also known as Sarvamitra.
Manual - English: As he grows up slightly, to a minimal extent, he learns letters with a teacher of letters, math with a math teacher, horse and elephant riding skills with Maternal Uncle, Mātulasulabha (bzang len), Archery and so forth with a teacher of weapons.

Sun of Faith - English: Krimivarman would write a script a give it to the Bodhisattava, who would say "I know this one. Give me another!"
Krimivarman wrote five hundred types of script and gave them each to the Boddhistattva. Every time was the same.
"I have written all of scripts in the world," he said, "I cannot find any more!"
Then the Bodhisattva wrote a script and showed it to Krmivarman, who did not know it.
Inscription - English:
The youth writing letters

Master Krmivarman

Sun of Faith - English: The Bodhisattva said, “This script becomes widespread when a bodhisattva or universal ruler appears in the world.”
At that moment, divine Brahma said from the sky, "It is just so."
The Bodhisattva then went to the Master of Mathematics Arjuna.
Inscription - English:
The youth

Arjuna, Master of mathematical subjects
Scene working notes: I could not find the Bodhisattva's study with the Mathematician, Arjuna (srid sgrub) in any Vinaya texts. The episode, however, appears in detail in the Latitavistara-sūtra (sde dge bka' 'gyur, vol. 46, 75b.2

Sun of Faith - English: Every mathematical topic that Arjuna taught, the Bodhisattva already knew. He spoke of figures and mathematical subjects that Arjuna didn't know a thing about.
The archery master Sahadeva taught him weaponry, including the the five kinds of of combat.
The Bodhisattava understood without relying on the masters' instruction, but the five hundred Shakya youths studied very hard to become trained.
The five kinds of combat are striking from a distance, striking by sound, striking the heart, striking by surprise, and striking with great intensity.
Aware of that Devadatta was filled with harmful intentions, the weapons master did not teach him to strike the heart.
